title: Structural Household Analysis using Revealed Preferences
descriptions:
This grant proposal, titled "Structural Household Analysis using Revealed Preferences", aims to revolutionize the understanding of household consumption patterns through non-unitary modeling techniques. The project will utilize an empirical toolkit based on revealed preference methodology with a nonparametric approach to analyze household consumption behavior. The key contributions of this research include the integration of marriage market dynamics into structural modeling and the incorporation of revealed preference restrictions with nonparametric estimation of demand systems.

The objectives of this project are to open the intrahousehold black box using aggregate consumption information, avoid parametric assumptions on decision processes, describe intrahousehold decision processes, and analyze household consumption patterns. By addressing challenges such as unobserved heterogeneity across households and the limited power of revealed preference restrictions, this research will provide valuable insights into the complexities of household decision-making.

Utilizing pooled cross-section data sets, this project will shed light on the intricacies of household consumption behavior and pave the way for more accurate and comprehensive modeling techniques in the field.

The proposed project, titled "Structural Household Analysis using Revealed Preferences," aims to revolutionize the understanding of household consumption patterns through non-unitary modeling techniques. By utilizing an empirical toolkit and a methodology rooted in revealed preference theory, the project seeks to address key challenges such as unobserved heterogeneity and limited power of revealed preference restrictions. The main contributions of this project include the integration of marriage market dynamics into structural modeling and the incorporation of revealed preference restrictions with nonparametric estimation of demand systems.

Through the analysis of pooled cross-section data sets, the project's objectives are to open the intrahousehold black box using aggregate consumption information, avoid parametric assumptions on decision processes, describe intrahousehold decision processes, and analyze household consumption patterns in depth. By providing a comprehensive and innovative approach to understanding household behavior, this project has the potential to reshape the field of household economics and contribute significantly to the advancement of economic theory.

This grant proposal seeks to conduct a project titled "Structural Household Analysis using Revealed Preferences" which aims to revolutionize the understanding of household consumption patterns through non-unitary modeling. The project will utilize an empirical toolkit to analyze household consumption behaviors using a revealed preference methodology with a nonparametric approach. The main contributions of this project include the integration of marriage market dynamics into structural modeling and the incorporation of revealed preference restrictions with nonparametric estimation of demand systems.

The objectives of the project are to open the intrahousehold black box using aggregate consumption information, avoid parametric assumptions on decision processes, describe intrahousehold decision processes, and analyze household consumption in a novel manner. The project addresses challenges such as unobserved heterogeneity across households and the limited power of revealed preference restrictions, using pooled cross-section data sets.

Overall, this project has the potential to provide valuable insights into household decision-making processes and consumption behaviors, leading to a more nuanced understanding of intrahousehold dynamics and potentially informing policy interventions.
